title: 111_hr3179
content: The Act titled "SIG TARP Small Business Awareness Act of 2009" recognizes the importance of small businesses in revitalizing the economy and highlights the challenges faced by small financial institutions in accessing funds from the Troubled Asset Relief Program. Witnesses in a hearing testified that small businesses are also struggling to obtain credit and financial products from banks and other financial institutions. The Act "SIG TARP Small Business Awareness Act of 2009" acknowledges the struggles of small financial institutions and businesses in accessing funds from the Troubled Asset Relief Program. The SIG TARP Small Business Awareness Act of 2009 addresses the impact of the Troubled Asset Relief Program on small financial institutions and businesses, ensuring adequate financial assistance and oversight. The Special Inspector General will examine the effects of financial assistance on small businesses under the Troubled Asset Relief Program, including positive and negative impacts by type and region. The Special Inspector General will report on the inclusion and utilization of women and minorities in each quarterly report to Congress, including information on the activities of the Secretary and financial institutions receiving assistance under the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008. The Special Inspector General will report on the inclusion and utilization of women, minorities, and women- and minority-owned businesses in financial assistance contracts under the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008. The quarterly report will include information on the levels of inclusion and utilization of these groups. The Special Inspector General will report on the inclusion and utilization of women, minorities, and women- and minority-owned businesses in financial assistance contracts under the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008, including details on contracts, dollar amounts, total numbers, and recommendations for increasing participation. The Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 requires the Special Inspector General to report on the participation of women, minorities, and women- and minority-owned businesses in financial assistance contracts. The bill was passed by the House of Representatives on September 15, 2009.
